 Relax! He's only nearly right, as delineated here.....
 
 
 " Consider two facts. First, it takes about 20 years for all vehicles on the road today to be replaced with newer, more efficient cars. That turnover rate could become even longer, because the economic downturn has left fewer people able to trade in older cars for newer vehicles, especially hybrids, diesels and some high-mpg gasoline options.
 
 And second, the most polluting cars on the road are the oldest. A study from California estimates that cars 13 years or older account for 25 percent of the miles driven-but 75 percent of pollution from cars. Officials from Texas say those clunkers spew 10 to 30 times as much pollution as newer cars. 
 
 Put the two facts together, and you can see why a handful of states-including California, Texas, Colorado, Delaware, Illinois, and Virginia-have started "Cash for Clunkers" programs. Texas offers as much as $3,500 for low-income consumers to ditch their clunkers and buy a new car. California gives $1,500 to help retire vehicles that fail emissions tests. And beginning in 2009, Canada will use a similar strategy to remove 50,000 clunkers from Canadian roads. ........ "
 
 
 http://www.hybridcars.com/incentives-laws/cash-clunkers-0727.html

Bt the clunker law as it was explained to me, had no exemptions for any vehicle over ten years old, it simply said all vehicles over ten years old could be seized by the state and then be recycled. As I said, this is how it was explained to me by my source, and that source is pretty accurate in my estimation.

 I don't know how many here are old enough to remember when the USA converted from Leaded to Unleaded gasoline, but it allowed enough years for cars that ran on leaded gas to age out of the system. After that predetermined date, They had to either be converted to Unleaded Gas or they just couldn't drive their cars since all stations only sold unleaded. 
 
 The same exact system was utilized when catalytic converters became mandatory for all cars, for pollution control laws. By a specified date all cars had to have them installed of they couldn't pass the State Inspection process.

 Wrong. Cars that were not manufactured with them are still not required to have them. There are different emissions standards for them. You cannot just retrofit a cat to something...it boosts back pressure and on some older enignes that were designed to run will little backpressure it actually makes them run worse.
 
 You are only halfway correct about unleaded. They stopped selling leaded gas in gas stations. You can still buy lead additive at autoparts stores if you need it. Generally you dont.

 I agree, I've heard the phrase "clunker law" on and off for decades. I think it's mostly hot air, and I don't think there's a chance of it in the near future, the aftermarket parts business, and private interest in old cars is just too big. Many if not most people, even those with no interest in cars, would agree that a government denial of ownership of something because of its age is as un-American as it gets. What would an 8 or 9 year old car be worth in a society like that? 
 
 I saw a message board discussion a year or so ago that was talking about private owners soon being unable to buy car paint anymore. Safety and pollution of course, the reasons most liberties are threatened. That was an issue for me since I used to paint cars for a living, and enjoy occasionally painting one for myself or a friend. The shop where I've always bought my paint heard nothing about it, and later I saw where it looks like private owners will eventually have limits on how much paint they can buy. One or two gallons per year. I don't like it, but I'll be able to live with that. 
 
 I don't think we'll see any more drastic measures than this, at least until after private ownership of guns is banned.

 I'd call that a "clunker program" more than a clunker law. A big difference, "programs" can be dressed up to look more innocent and meaningful than mandatory laws. But they're a slippery slope, programs can easily slide into laws. 
 
 
So why bother posting it? 

 
 It's legitimate to wonder who proposes and seeks these kinds of laws, and what their problem is.
